header.title: THE CONTROLLED REMOTE VIEWING MANUAL
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Remote Viewing, Psychic Development

central_thesis: The Controlled Remote Viewing (CRV) Manual outlines a rigorous, multi-stage methodology for psychoenergetic perception, designed to achieve reliable acquisition and description of non-local information. By adhering to a strict 'structure' and managing 'noise' (Analytic Overlays, environmental/personal factors), practitioners can access data from a universal 'Matrix' via a 'signal line,' progressing from general gestalts to detailed three-dimensional models of target sites.

structure_content.summary: Defines Remote Viewing (RV) as psychoenergetic perception and Coordinate Remote Viewing (CRV) as RV using geographic coordinates. Introduces the roles of Remote Viewer and Monitor. Explains the session setup in a controlled environment designed to minimize distractions, where the Monitor provides coordinates and the Viewer generates verbal and sketched responses. Post-session, both review and discuss results after obtaining target feedback. Historically, CRV was developed by SRI-International in early 1980 to enhance RV reliability through controlled factors (reporting format, viewing chamber, interviewer patter) across six progressive training stages.

Postulates a non-material 'Matrix' containing all universal information, accessed via a 'signal line' perceived by the viewer. The signal line is 'encoded' information received through the autonomic nervous system and 'decoded' by the viewer into objectified data. 'Aperture' controls the flow of signal energy, starting 'narrow' in Stage I and widening in later stages. The theory models consciousness with unconscious, subconscious, limen, liminal, and conscious levels, asserting that the signal line first impinges on the unconscious and is then transmitted reflexively through the Autonomic Nervous System, manifesting as an 'ideogram.' The 'conscious' mind, with its linear analytic processes, tends to generate 'Analytic Overlay' (AOL) by prematurely assigning coherence to perceived data, requiring structured management to prevent distortion.

Emphasizes 'quitting on a high point' to reinforce correct neurological pathways, contrasting with rote repetition. Defines 'Overtraining' as system saturation leading to psychic dysfunction, countered by training breaks for 'absorption.' Introduces 'Cognitron' as neural assemblages storing composite concepts, with 'Neurons' and 'Synapses' as physical building blocks. 'First-Time Effect' describes initial high success due to dormant psi channels 'catching the analytic system off guard,' followed by a drop in performance as analytic processes generate 'Noise' (masking 'mental noise' or AOL). Proper 'Noise' management is crucial for distinguishing valid signal from internal processes. Progression between the six CRV stages is based on consistent control and replication of stage elements and 'noise-free' operation, culminating in summation essays.

Defines 'Structure' as the systematic, orderly process of transitioning from general to specific information acquisition from the signal line, objectifying all data and phenomena, and rigorously extracting AOL. This is executed via a formal, ordered, paper-and-pen format. 'Inclemencies' (personal/environmental factors) must be identified and objectified to prevent data degradation. 'Objectification' (verbal and written) records data, expels non-signal line 'noise,' and provides feedback to the system. The 'I/A/B Sequence' (Ideogram, 'A' component for feeling/motion, 'B' component for first analytic response) is the foundational element for site acquisition. Various 'Feedback' types (Correct, Probably Correct, Near Site, Can't Feed Back, Site, Silence) guide the viewer in early training, reinforcing correct responses and maintaining connection to the signal line. 'Self-Correcting Characteristic' ensures ideograms re-present if improperly decoded. Seven types of 'Breaks' (AOL, Confusion, Too Much, Aesthetic Impact, AOL Drive, Bi-location, General) provide mechanisms to 'hold' the system, flush out AOLs, and make adjustments for a fresh start. Structure is paramount: 'Structure! Content be damned!'

Focuses on acquiring the site's 'Major Gestalt' – its overall, unique impression. The viewer attunes to the signal line to decode and objectify this gestalt and major information pieces. All CRV sessions begin with Stage I, emphasizing correct structure for accuracy. The core 'I/A/B Formation' involves writing the coordinate, spontaneously drawing an 'Ideogram' (I) representing the gestalt, then describing its 'A' Component (feeling/motion, e.g., solidity, liquidity, energetic, airiness, temperature), and finally the 'B' Component (first instantaneous analytic response, e.g., 'mountain,' 'water'). Ideograms can be Single, Double, Multiple, or Composite, with their 'Vertical/Horizontal Orientation' determined by the 'A' component, not visual appearance. Stage I training is divided into Phase I (single major gestalt sites) and Phase II (multiple major gestalts with interfaces). Drills encourage spontaneity and flexibility in ideogram production.

Progresses to acquiring 'Sensory Data' related to the physical senses (touch, smell, sight, sound, taste), temperature, and 'energetics.' The 'Aperture' widens after Stage I, allowing more detailed, slower-incoming sensory information. Responses often appear as 'Clusters' of 'Basic' words (simple, fundamental sensory descriptions like 'rough,' 'red,' 'cold'). More complex words are 'out of structure' and unreliable. 'Dimensionals' (vertical-ness, horizontal-ness, angularity, space/volume, mass) begin to emerge towards the end of Stage II, signaling a shift in perspective from global gestalt. Analytic Overlay (AOL) is rarer here due to the basic sensory nature, perceived as fuzzy/indistinct images rather than sharp/static AOLs from Stage I. Aesthetic Impact (AI) may occur, signaling transition to Stage III.

Marked by a dramatic widening of the aperture, the emergence of more comprehensive 'Dimensionals,' and the trigger of 'Aesthetic Impact' (AI) – the viewer's subjective emotional response to the site. The goal is 'command of structure.' Key elements include 'Motion' (activity at the site) and 'Mobility' (viewer's ability to shift viewpoint). Dimensional data is organized using 'Sketches' (rapid, general representations, distinct from deliberate drawings) and 'Trackers' (series of dots/dashes describing contours). 'Spontaneous Ideograms' can occur during sketching, relating to sub-gestalts. 'Movement/Movement Exercises' involve shifting focus to secondary sites using polar coordinates ('8 1/2 miles northwest something should be visible') with neutral, passive prompting to avoid AOL. AOL in Stage III includes 'AOL Matching' (AOL nearly matching the site, requiring 'seeing through') and 'AOL Drive' (system caught in a feedback loop of AOL, leading to 'Ratcheting' or 'AOL Peacocking'), necessitating an 'AOL/D Break'.

Deals with the 'enormous flood' of information after Stage III, requiring a 'systemic structure' for orderly management and to facilitate focus on finer details. This is achieved through an 'information matrix' with column headings: S-2 (Stage II sensory data), D (Dimensionals), AI (Aesthetic Impact), EI (Emotional Impact), T (Tangibles), I (Intangibles), AOL (Analytic Overlay), and AOL/S (AOL/Signal). 'Emotional Impact' (EI) refers to perceived emotions of people at the site or the site itself. 'Tangibles' (T) are physical objects/characteristics. 'Intangibles' (I) are abstract qualities or purposes. 'AOL/S' (AOL/Signal) is when an AOL closely matches the site, allowing information use without a break. The matrix is filled from left-to-right, top-to-bottom, in 'clusters' representing site portions. Viewers can influence information retrieval by placing their pen in a specific column to prompt that data type.

A unique stage that bypasses direct signal line access, instead retrieving information 'stored' in 'cognitrons' below the liminal threshold, imprinted during earlier stages. This involves breaking down a 'cognitron-concept' (e.g., 'religious') into sub-elements called 'emanations.' Prompting is 'hypo-stimulative,' using categories (Objects, Attributes, Subjects, Topics) followed by 'Emanations?' to avoid AOL. Objects are physical items, Attributes are characteristics, Subjects are nominative functions or abstract intangibles, and Topics are specific sub-elements of subjects. The process is 'hierarchical and fractalized,' allowing further subdivision. 'Switches' occur when emanations from a different category intrude. AOLs encountered in Stage V are declared normally, but 'Prior Emanations' can be derived from valid AOLs, seen as 'kernels' of site information, via a 'stage-fiving' process.

Involves three-dimensional modeling of the site (e.g., with clay) to kinesthetically interact and assess temporal and spatial relationships. This activity serves to 'quench the desire to produce AOL' and prompts further site information, lowering the viewer's liminal threshold by narrowing attention to specific locales/times. The 'detect mode' of kinesthetic activity involves creating sketches/models, while the 'decode mode' involves objectifying the information into a Stage VI Matrix (identical in form to Stage IV, but specific to the modeled locale/time). The focus is on the 'objectified information' generated during modeling, not the precision of the model itself. Stage VI can be engaged after Stage IV and/or V, or once Stage IV is stabilized and localized on a specific site aspect.

key_concepts.definition: The name of a method of psychoenergetic perception. A term coined by SRI-International and defined as 'the acquisition and description, by mental means, of information blocked from ordinary perception by distance, shielding or time.'
The process of remote viewing using geographic coordinates for cueing or prompting.

A person who employs his mental faculties to perceive and obtain information to which he has no other access and of which he has no previous knowledge concerning persons, places, events, or objects separated from him by time, distance, or other intervening obstacles.

The individual who assists the viewer in a remote viewing session. The monitor provides the coordinate, observes the viewer to help insure he stays in proper structure (discussed below), records relevant session information, provides appropriate feedback when required, and provides objective analytic support to the viewer as necessary.

Something within which something else originates or takes form or develops. A place or point of origin or growth. Described as a huge, non-material, highly structured, mentally accessible 'framework' of information containing all data pertaining to everything in both the physical and non-physical universe.
The hypothesized train of signals emanating from the Matrix (discussed below) and perceived by the remote viewer, which transports the information obtained through the remote viewing process.

An opening or open space; hole, gap, cleft, chasm, slit. In radar, the electronic gate that controls the width and dispersion pattern of the radiating signal or wave. In CRV, it controls the portion of the signal line allowed to access consciousness.
A unified whole; a configuration, pattern, or organized field having specific properties that cannot be derived from the summation of its component parts.

The reflexive mark made on the paper as a result of the impingement of the signal on the autonomic nervous system and its subsequent transmittal through this system to the arm and hand muscles, which transfers it through the pen onto the paper.
The 'feeling/motion' component of the ideogram. Essentially the impression of the physical consistency (hard, soft, solid, fluid, gaseous, etc.) and contour/shape/motion of the site.
The first (spontaneous) analytic response to the ideogram and 'A' component.

Conscious subjective interpretation of signal line data, which may or may not be relevant to the site. It is the mind's conscious analytic process jumping to conclusions about incoming incomprehensible data.
Allows the signal line to be put on hold while AOL is expelled from the system.

With the expansion in aperture inherent in Stage III, and after appropriate AI, the AOL phenomenon develops to where a viewer's AOL may match or nearly match the actual signal line impression of the site.

Virtually synonymous with 'AOL Matching,' occurs when an AOL produced by the viewer's analytic mental machinery almost exactly matches the site, and the viewer can to some extent 'look' through the AOL image to perceive the actual site.

Occurs when the viewer's system is caught up in an AOL to the extent that the viewer at least temporarily believes he is on the signal line, even though he is not. Indicated by repeating signals, blackness, or 'peacocking.'
The recurrence of the same AOL over and over again as if trapped in a feedback loop.
The rapid unfolding, one right after another, of a series of brilliant AOLs, each building from one before, analogous to the unfolding of a peacock's tail.

The act of physically saying out loud and writing down information. Serves to record and expel information, make the system aware of its contributions, allow re-input for prompting, and 'give reality' to the signal line.
Personal considerations that might degrade or even preclude psychic functioning. (e.g., muscle pains, colds, allergies, stress, hunger, need to eliminate body wastes).

The mechanism developed to allow the system to be put on 'hold,' providing the opportunity to flush out AOLs, deal with temporary inclemencies, or make system adjustments, allowing a fresh start with new momentum. Seven types are defined: AOL, Confusion, Too Much, Aesthetic Impact, AOL Drive, Bi-location, and General Break.
The tendency of the ideogram to re-present itself if improperly or incompletely decoded. Informs the viewer of an error in procedure.
An assemblage of neurons, linked together by interconnecting synapses, which when stimulated by the mind's recall system produce a composite concept of their various subparts.
Sub-elements or component parts of a cognitron, brought forth in Stage V through specific prompting. Literally defined as 'to issue from a source, to flow forth, to emit, or to issue'.
Words produced by the viewer and written down in structure to conceptualize perceived elements of dimensional perspective (vertical-ness, horizontal-ness, angularity, space/volume, mass).

The perceived emotions or feelings of the people at the site or of the viewer. Sometimes the site itself possesses an element of emotional impact, which is imprinted with long or powerful associations with human emotional response.
Objects or characteristics at the site which have solid, 'touchable' impact on the perceptions of the viewer (e.g., tables, chairs, buildings, smells, colors).
Qualities of the site that are perhaps abstract or not specifically defined by tangible aspects (e.g., purposes, non-physical qualities, categorizations like 'governmental,' 'medical,' 'business').

In Stage VI, interaction with the site by describing it with 3-dimensional materials (e.g., modeling with clay) to assess relative temporal and spatial elements, and to lower the liminal threshold by narrowing the viewer's attention field to specific locales.

practical_system.description: The CRV system is a six-stage, paper-and-pen methodology for Coordinate Remote Viewing, mediated by a 'Monitor' and conducted in a controlled environment. The system's core operative principle is to access information from a non-material 'Matrix' via a 'signal line' and 'objectify' (verbally and in writing) the perceived data in a strict, progressive 'structure.' This structure is designed to filter out 'Analytic Overlays' (AOLs) and other forms of 'noise,' enhancing the purity and reliability of psychic impressions. The system emphasizes iterative prompting with geographic coordinates and a systematic breakdown of perceived information from broad gestalts to specific details and three-dimensional modeling.
tools: Dedicated remote viewing room (acoustic-tiled, featureless, homogeneous, dimmable light)
Modeling material (e.g., clay for Stage VI)
rituals: **Session Initialization (General):** Viewer writes name, date/time, and declares any 'Inclemencies' (personal distractions) to 'purge the system' before receiving the coordinate.

**Stage I (I/A/B Formation):** Monitor provides coordinate. Viewer writes it on the left, then spontaneously draws an 'Ideogram' (I) in the middle. Immediately, the viewer identifies the 'A' Component (feeling/motion) and writes it on the right. Then, identifies the 'B' Component (first analytic response) and writes it below 'A.' This sequence is repeated as prompted.

**Stage II (Sensory Data):** Following I/A/B, the viewer records 'Sensory Data' (S-2) in 'clusters' of 'basic' words (touch, taste, sound, color, odor, temperature, energetics). 'Dimensionals' (tall, wide, long, big) begin to emerge towards the end of this stage.

**Stage III (Dimensionality & Aesthetic Impact):** Viewer experiences 'Aesthetic Impact' (AI), a subjective emotional response, which must be declared as 'AI Break' and allowed to dissipate. Then, the viewer produces 'Spontaneous Sketches' or 'Trackers' to represent dimensional aspects. 'Movement/Movement Exercises' may be performed by receiving polar coordinate prompts (e.g., '8 1/2 miles northwest something should be visible') and objectifying the new site's I/A/B.

**Stage IV (Information Matrix):** Viewer organizes incoming information into a pre-drawn matrix with columns: S-2, D, AI, EI, T (Tangibles), I (Intangibles), AOL, AOL/S. The viewer can influence data retrieval by placing their pen in a desired column.

**Stage V (Cognitron Emanations):** Viewer accesses sub-elements ('emanations') of previously identified concepts (cognitrons) by prompting with the concept, then a category (Objects, Attributes, Subjects, or Topics), followed by 'Emanations?'. Responses are recorded as a list, maintaining a smooth, spontaneous flow. 'AOL' can be 'stage-fived' to extract 'prior emanations.'

**Stage VI (3D Modeling):** Viewer uses modeling material (e.g., clay) to construct a 3D model of the site's tangibles. While modeling, the viewer maintains focus on the 'signal line' and 'objectifies' emerging details into a Stage VI Matrix (similar to Stage IV).

**Break Protocols:** During any stage, various 'Breaks' (e.g., AOL Break, Confusion Break, Too Much Break, Bi-location Break) are declared and objectified to manage mental states, discharge 'noise,' and recalibrate the session.

relevant_quotes.text: This manual does not, and cannot, replace personal instruction in the psychic methodology of Controlled Remote Viewing.

As will be explained in greater detail below, remote viewing theory postulates a non-material "Matrix" in which any and all information about any person, place or thing may be obtained through the agency of a hypothesized "signal line."

Essentially, the mind jumps to one or a number of instantaneous conclusions about the incoming information without waiting for sufficient information to make an accurate judgement. This process is completely reflexive, and happens even when not desired by the individual involved.
"Structure! Content be damned!" is the universal motto of the remote viewer. As long as proper structure is maintained, information obtained may be relied on.
The viewer may not work through AI. Aesthetic Impact must be recognized, declared, and allowed to thoroughly dissipate.
It is the objectified information resulting from the modeling that is IMPORTANT.

critical_analysis.relevance: The CRV Manual presents a highly formalized, pseudo-scientific approach to clairvoyance, distinct from many intuitive or ceremonial magical practices. Its military origin and emphasis on replicability, control of 'noise' (AOLs), and systematic progression through 'stages' offers a structured magical system for psychic perception. While not directly tied to traditional occult currents like Qabalah or Hermeticism, its rigorous methodology for accessing non-local information via a 'signal line' from a 'Matrix' can be seen as a modern Western Esoteric technology. The meticulous categorization of data (sensory, dimensional, emotional, tangible, intangible) and the management of internal interference (AOLs, inclemencies, breaks) provide a robust framework for practical 'scrying' or information gathering, aligning with the operative aims of some Chaos Magic or modern magical paradigms seeking quantifiable results in psychic work. The concept of 'objectification' as a means of 'giving reality' to the signal resonates with magical principles of verbal and written declaration to manifest intent.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This manual is primarily suited for disciplined individuals, researchers, and practitioners within Western Esotericism and Occultism who seek a structured, systematic, and analytical approach to psychic development, particularly remote viewing. It appeals to those interested in the 'how-to' of mental faculties for information acquisition, emphasizing rigorous practice over intuitive talent. It is also relevant for students of parapsychology and those studying intelligence-related psi programs. It would be less suitable for practitioners preferring purely intuitive, ecstatic, or less formalized magical systems.
